prep.text: and when you enter a museum, you become part of a public
michael warner - what is a public?

writeups:
Michael Warner is a professor of American Literature at Yale, and is considered one of the founding members of queer theory in the US. This specific reading is part of a book-length series on publics in general, trying to elucidate what a public really is.

A public, in this case, is created as the result of multiple connections: the connection between a discourse and a set of strangers receiving that discourse and between those strangers themselves.

When you enter a museum, you become part of a public. You are still, to a certain extent, free of whether or not you want to completely integrate that public (e.g. socialites at art openings) or if you are just subjected to it without agreeing.

prep.text: the public sphere is "a virtual or imaginary community which does not necessarily exist in any identifiable space" and in which private persons discuss about public matters. - jurgen habermas
the public sphere has been the dominant way to think about publics from a national point of view.
the public sphere is a singular term, it assumes the unicity of the public in modern democratic societies

writeups: One the one side, the public sphere (1962, The Strucutural Transformation of the Public Sphere) was a an ideal community in which ideas and discussions flowed freely, building upon freedom of the speech, freedom of the press, freedom of association.

On the other side, Nancy Fraser has seen it as misrepresenting the multiplicity of publics within a democracy: it is not just one big coherent whole. The idea of a single public is already an assumption, and this assumption is often taken in by museums, who consider their publics in a very fixed manner.

prep.text: "the museum is important for those who go there, insofar as it allows them to distinguish themselves from those who do not go there." -pierre bourdieu

writeups: There are multiple facets to what museums are. One of them is the maintaining of the status quo. Recently, there are multiple initiatives to develop a more open attitude towards the local population, and  therefore a multiplicity of publics.
There is a feedback loop between museums and their publics: they need to have people come to maintain a certain legitimacy, and people go in order to create legitimacy.

prep.text: what does bourdieu mean by consumption of culture?
tangible value creation

writeups: The implication here is that of cultural capital. That financial capital is not the only asset that one can accumulate in the journey towards class ascension, but that there is also social capital, and cultural capital.
The arts do create economic value, and it is interesting to wonder why. One aspect of it is the merging of art and creativity, because creativity does imply economic value.
But they also create something intangible, and that something is cultural capital, a way to demonstrate social status and social mobility.
